**

Summary of requirements:

Add a warning to the start of the process that prompts Admin to check that the records for these members have been set up correctly.

Enable Admin to add the increase percentage against new notional elements that will be created.

Apply the percentage added in step 2 to the notional elements.

Identify whether the sum of the new values of the notional elements are higher than the sum of the PIE elements (which are non increasing), and if so, to include the notional elements into the total new value instead of the PIE elements.

Add a Y/N marker on the output for when the sum of the notional elements have exceeded the sum of the PIE elements.

Add a warning at the end of the process that will prompt Admin to update the records for the members where the underpin has bitten (Admin would have to zero the notional elements, create normal GMP elements, zero the PIE elements, and create notional PIE elements. The procedure carried out is as follows:

# Lookup the latest S52, S101 year that is available (currently 2025)
# Lookup the year of date of calculation (could be DOR, or the specific elements normal pension age date / normal retirement date depending on DOR)
# Calculate the complete number of years from date of leaving to date of calculation above.
# Calculate future unknown years by taking the year of date of calculation and minus the latest s52/s101. 
# Known years is therefore complete years - future years.

In the case provided in the ticket this would translate as follows:  

# Latest S52 = 2025
# Year of date of calculation = 2030 (Each element has a normal pension age date of 01/05/2030).
# Complete number of years from DOL 30/06/1999 to normal pension age date above = 30.
# Future years is 2030 - 2025 = 5
# Known years to use is 30 - 5 = 25.

Hello,

I have looked into this and either made coding updates or explained the reason behind our calculations, where we think the results are appropriate. 

I think the difference lies in the fact that Aurora will always use the latest factors available, where the revaluation end date is in the future. As these members are revaluing past DOR, to NPA, the code uses all known factors up to 2025 (even if past DOR, since the factor is known) and then uses 2.5% for any unknown years. There is no reason for the code to not apply the 2025 known s52 order, even if DOR is in 2024, as the revaluation end date is past 2025 for all of the cases provided.

I have set workings out below.

*_CASE 1:_*

Member 822175: Cat UNG

* Instructed during coding: if{{the date of retirement is before the normal pension age date, revalue to normal pension age date}}
* DOR: 17/12/2024
* NPA Date: 17/12/2029
* Leaving Date: 22/04/2002
* Years to revalue: 23 known years to 2025, 4 assumed years to 2029
* 23 known years = 1.904 (2025 orders)
* 4 assumed years = 1.025 (rate given by admin) ^ 4 = 1.1038*

**This is a correction we have made to the code after reviewing this query. Originally we calculated this as 5 years (age at NPA (60) less age at retirement (55) = 5 years) but this was resulting in a double counting of 1 year.*

As such, I think the calc is now correctly revaluing to a total of 27 years from DOL to NPA, it is just that Aurora gets 23 and 4 years, not 22 and 5 years. This makes sense, seen as the revaluation is up to 2029 and we have 2025 factors available, so would use all available years, before applying the assumed 2.5%.



*_CASE 2:_*

* DOR: 09/12/2024
* NPA Date: 09/04/2026, so revalue to NPA as after DOR
* Leaving Date: 30/09/1995

* 1 assumed year = 1.025 (rate given by admin) ^ 1 = 1.025

So the above named scheme is an anniversary PINCs (i.e. the increase is based on the day they retired). Members are also paid on the day they retired, too. The payroll period covers 6th-5th.

I am happy to have a discussion about this, or whether my suggestion is feasible, but I think what may work and be beneficial is having PINC groups.

so, those that retired between 6th April - 5th May would have the PINC group P1.
6th May - 5th June PINC group P2. 

Etc.

Please let me know if this can be implemented and how we'd go about it.
